REMARKS: Defining parameters semi-major axis, flattening and angular velocity are same as for GRS 1980 (ellipsoid code 7019); GM = 3986004.4e8 m*m*m/s/s (from NASA 1986 Lageos determination).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Chinese Academy of Surveying and Mapping.

REMARKS: Original definition is a=20923713, b=20853810 feet of 1796. 1/f is given to 7 decimal places. For the 1936 retriangulation OSGB defines the relationship of 10 feet of 1796 to the International metre through ([10^0.48401603]/10) exactly = 0.3048007491...
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Ordnance Survey of Great Britain.

REMARKS: OSGB Airy 1830 figure (ellipsoid code 7001) rescaled by 0.999965 to best fit the scale of the 19th century primary triangulation of Ireland.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "The Irish Grid - A Description of the Co-ordinate Reference System" published by Ordnance Survey of Ireland, Dublin and Ordnance Survey of Northern Ireland, Belfast.

REMARKS: Based on the GRS 1967 figure but with 1/f taken to 2 decimal places exactly.  The dimensions are also used as the GRS 1967 Modified ellipsoid (see code 7050).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Australian Map Grid Technical Manual"; National Mapping Council of Australia Special Publication #7; 1972

REMARKS: Original Bessel definition is a=3272077.14 and b=3261139.33 toise. This used a weighted mean of values from several authors but did not account for differences in the length of the various toise: the "Bessel toise" is therefore of uncertain length.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: US Army Map Service Technical Manual; 1943.

REMARKS: Used in Norway and also in Sweden with a 1mm increase in semi-major axis.
a = 6377397.155 German legal metres. This is the same value as the Bessel 1841 figure (code 7004) but in different units.  Used in Namibia.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping, Mowbray, South Africa.

REMARKS: Clarke's 1858/II solution. Derived parameters: a = 6378293.645m using his 1865 ratio of 0.3047972654 feet per metre; 1/f = 294.26068…  In Australia and Amoco Trinidad 1/f taken to two decimal places (294.26 exactly); elsewhere a and b used to derive 1/f.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)" by Georg Strasser.

REMARKS: Original definition a=20926062 and b=20855121 (British) feet. Uses Clarke's 1865 inch-metre ratio of 39.370432 to obtain metres. (Metric value then converted to US survey feet for use in the United States using 39.37 exactly giving a=20925832.16 ft US).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: US Army Map Service Technical Manual No. 7; 1943.

REMARKS: Used for Michigan NAD27 State Plane zones.  Radius = ellipsoid radius + 800 feet; this approximates the average elevation of the state.   Derived parameter: 1/f = 294.97870
INFORMATION_SOURCE: USGS Professional Paper #1395.

REMARKS: Adopts Clarke's values for a and b.  Uses Benoit's 1895 ratio of 0.9143992 metres per yard to convert to metres.
Adopts Clarke's values for a and b using his 1865 ratio of 39.370432 inches per metre to convert axes to metres.
Adopts Clarke's values for a and 1/f.  Adopts his 1865 ratio of 39.370432 inches per metre to convert semi-major axis to metres. Also known as Clarke Modified 1880.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Empire Survey Review #32; 1939.

REMARKS: Adopts Clarke's value for a with derived 1/f.  Uses his 1865 ratio of 39.370432 inch per metre to convert semi-major axis to metres.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping, Mowbray, South Africa.

REMARKS: Used in Old French Triangulation (ATF).   Uses Clarke's 1865 inch-metre ratio of 39.370432 to convert axes to metres.

Used for the 1937 readjustment of Indian triangulation.  Clarke's 1865 Indian-British foot ratio (0.99999566) and Benoit's 1898 British inch-metre ratio (39.370113) rounded as 0.30479841 exactly and applied to Everest's 1830 definition taken as a and 1/f
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Survey of India professional paper #28; 1939

REMARKS: Adopted 1967 for use in East Malaysia.  Applies Sears 1922 inch-metre ratio of 39.370147 to Everest 1830 original definition of a and 1/f but with a taken to be in British rather than Indian feet.
Adopted 1967 for use in West Malaysia.  Applies Benoit 1898 inch-metre ratio of 39.370113 to Everest 1830 original definition of a and 1/f but with a taken to be in British rather than Indian feet.

Adopted by IUGG 1979 Canberra.  Inverse flattening is derived from geocentric gravitational constant GM = 3986005e8 m*m*m/s/s; dynamic form factor J2 = 108263e8 and Earth's angular velocity = 7292115e-11 rad/s.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Geodetic Reference System 1980" by H. Moritz; Bulletin Geodesique

REMARKS: Helmert 1906/III solution.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)" by Georg Strasser

REMARKS: Based on the GRS 1967 figure but with 1/f taken to 3 decimal places exactly.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Rais paper.

REMARKS: Adopted by IUGG 1924 in Madrid. Based on Hayford 1909/1910 figures.
Used by Transit Precise Ephemeris between October 1971 and January 1987.
Rescaling of Delambre 1810 figure (a=6376985 m) to make meridional arc from equator to pole equal to 10000000 metres exactly. (Ref: Strasser).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: IGN Paris "Constants d'Ellipsoides" February 1972.

REMARKS: Original definition of semi-major axis given as 3272539 toise.  In "Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)" , Strasser suggests a conversion factor of 1.94903631 which gives a=6378297.337 metres.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Geodesia y Cartografia Matematica" by Fernando Martin Asin; ISBN 84-398-0248-X.

REMARKS: In non-metric form, a=20926201 Gold Coast feet. DMA Technical Manual 8358.1 and data derived from this quotes value for semi-major axis as 6378300.58m: OGP recommends use of defined value 6378300m exactly.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Tables for the use of the Gold Coast Survey Department, 1935.

REMARKS: Inverse flattening derived from four defining parameters (semi-major axis; C20 = -484.16685*10e-6; earth's angular velocity w = 7292115e11 rad/sec; gravitational constant GM = 3986005e8 m*m*m/s/s).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: DMA Technical Manual 8350.2-B

REMARKS: Used for  GEM 10C Gravity Potential Model.
Used for OSU86 gravity potential (geoidal) model.
Used for OSU91 gravity potential (geoidal) model.
Clarke gave a and b and also 1/f=293.465 (to 3 decimal places exactly). In the 19th century b was normally given as the second defining parameter.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)" by Georg Strasser.

REMARKS: Authalic sphere.  1/f is infinite. Superseded by GRS 1980 authalic sphere (code 7047).

Adopted by IUGG 1967 Lucerne.  Inverse flattening given is derived from geocentric gravitational constant (GM)= 398603e9 m*m*m/s/s; dynamic form factor (J2) = 0.0010827 and Earth's angular velocity w = 7.2921151467e-5 rad/s. See also GRS 1967 (SAD69).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Geodetic Reference System 1967"; International Association of Geodesy special publication number 3; August 1971.
New Brunswick Geographic Information Corporation land and water information standards manual

REMARKS: Everest gave a and b to 2 decimal places and also 1/f=300.8017 (to 4 decimal places exactly). In the 19th century b was normally given as the second defining parameter.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Ellipsoidisch Parameter der Erdfigur (1800-1950)" by Georg Strasser

REMARKS: Used by Pakistan since metrication.  Clarke's 1865 Indian foot-British foot ratio (0.99999566) and his 1865 British inch-metre ratio (39.369971) rounded with slight error as 1 Ind ft = 0.3047995m exactly and applied to Everest's 1830 definition of a & b.

Used by India since metrication.  Clarke's 1865 Indian foot-British foot ratio (0.99999566) and his 1865 British inch-metre ratio (39.369971) rounded as 1 Ind ft = 0.3047995m exactly applied to Everest's 1830 original definition taken as a and b.

The semi-major axis has the same value as the Bessel 1841 ellipsoid (code 7004) but is in different units - German Legal Metres rather than International metres - hence a different size.  a = 6377483.865 International metres. Used in Namibia.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Chief Directorate: Surveys and Mapping, Mowbray, South Africa.

REMARKS: Authalic sphere derived from Clarke 1866 ellipsoid (code 7008).  Deprecated as name and parameter values do not match; replaced by 7048.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: OGP

REMARKS: Authalic sphere derived from GRS 1980 ellipsoid (code 7019).  (An authalic sphere is one with a surface area equal to the surface area of the ellipsoid). 1/f is infinite.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: OGP
Chinese Sceience Bulletin, 2009, 54:2714-2721.

REMARKS: Based on the GRS 1967 figure (code 7036) but with 1/f taken to 2 decimal places exactly. Used with SAD69 and TWD67 datums. The dimensions are also used as the Australian National Spheroid (code 7003).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: "Geodetic Reference System 1967"; International Association of Geodesy special publication number 3; August 1971.

REMARKS: Semi-major axis originally given as 3271883.25 toise. Uses toise to French metre ratio of 1.94903631 to two decimal place precision. An alternative ratio with the German legal metre of 1.9490622 giving 6377104m has not been used in Danish work.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Kort og Matrikelstyrelsen (KMS), Copenhagen.

REMARKS: Authalic sphere derived from Clarke 1866 ellipsoid (code 7008).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: OGP
DMA / NIMA / NGA TR8350.2
Geodeziya i Katografiya, 1993.

REMARKS: Clark'es 1880 definition in feet assumed for the purposes of metric conversion to be international foot. a = 6378306.370…metres. 1/f derived from a and b = 293.4663077… Used in Fiji.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Department of Lands and Survey, Fiji.

REMARKS: Adopted for 1969 metrication of peninsula Malaysia RSO grid.  Uses Sears 1922 yard-metre ratio truncated to 6 significant figures applied to Everest 1830 original definition of a and 1/f but with a taken to be in British rather than Indian feet.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Defence Geographic Centre

REMARKS: Authalic sphere derived from International 1924 ellipsoid (code 7022).
INFORMATION_SOURCE: OGP

REMARKS: Used in US DMSP SSM/I microwave sensor processing software. Semi-minor axis derived from eccentricity=0.081816153. Semi-major axis (a) sometimes given as 3443.992nm which OGP suspects is a derived approximation. OGP conversion assumes 1nm=1852m exactly.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: US National Snow and Ice Data Center

REMARKS: Sphere with radius equal to the semi-major axis of the GRS80 and WGS 84 ellipsoids. Used only for Web approximate mapping and visualisation. Not recognised by geodetic authorities.
INFORMATION_SOURCE: Microsoft.
